embodies our commitment to owning as 
well as developing resilient power 
infrastructure and fostering long-term 
partnerships that fuel progress and 
sustainability.

Semi Annual Report 2025-26
Dear Unitholders,
It is my privilege to present to you the 
semi-annual report for HI FY 2025–26. 
These last six months have been a 
standing testimony on delivery of our 
vision set eight years back, of creating 
unitholder value, chasing sustainable 
growth and creating an impactful 
energy delivery platform. 
While pursuing this, not only have we 
delivered a total return of 174% at a 
staggering annualised rate of 13%, but 
we have also added a robust  
INR 60+ Billion development pipeline, 
which is poised to grow further with the 
upcoming bid pipeline.
Growth has been a steady pillar in our 
pursuit of excellence, and with ever 
evolving grid and dynamically 
changing stakeholders, our key focus 
going forward from here is to ensure 
that IndiGrid evolves into a diversified 
and future-ready energy 
infrastructure platform – one that not 
only delivers predictable cash flows 
but is equally attuned to India’s 
energy transition priorities.
Evolving Sector Landscape and 
Structural Opportunity
The energy sector in India is 
undergoing a massive transformation, 
with greener energy mix, evolving 
delivery models and increasing 
number of use cases across industries 
in mobility and manufacturing. As the 
generation mix shifts towards 
renewables and peak demand 
accelerates, transmission and 
storage infrastructure will play a 
defining role in enabling grid flexibility, 
reliability, and last-mile delivery.
By current estimates, India’s peak 
power demand is expected to cross 
360 GW by 2032, requiring ~900 GW of 
installed generation capacity – over 
two thirds of which is anticipated to 
come from renewable sources. This 
shift will necessitate a corresponding 
ramp-up in transmission capacity  
(~1,70,000 ckms), transformation 
capacity (~1,200 GVA), and grid-scale 
partnership with British International 
Investment (BII) and Norfund, to 
develop greenfield transmission and 
standalone battery energy storage 
projects in India. 
EnerGrid leverages IndiGrid’s strong 
execution track record and 
understanding of the Indian energy 
sector, while BII and Norfund bring 
long-term capital and global 
expertise in climate-focussed 
infrastructure. Together, the platform 
aims to create a robust pipeline of 
projects that will eventually be 
acquired by IndiGrid post- 
commissioning, offering a capital- 
efficient route to growth.
The seeds of collaboration have now 
started to stem up on the solid 
foundation built, with over 50% of the 
commitment already identified for 
deployment till date. 
Given the execution capability of the 
team and the unique positioning of 
EnerGrid, we see significant long-
term impact being created by 
EnerGrid, deploying more and more 
capital meaningfully in the coming 
years.
ESG – Embedded, Evolving, and 
Measurable
The pillar of growth is built on the 
foundations of sustainability. 
Sustainability is embedded into our 
platform, partnerships, and decisions. 
Envisaged over the last few years, our 
ESG strategy has evolved further, 
adding clear metrics, aligning internal 
systems, and enhancing governance 
structures continuously.
Our partnerships with BII, Norfund, 
GEAPP, and IFC reflect the confidence 
that global climate capital places in 
our ability to deliver measurable 
environmental and social outcomes. 
The embodiment of global best 
practices now starts at the 
development stage continuing into 
the operational stage, with a clear 
The year so far has been 
focused on meaningful 
capacity addition. On 
one hand, we acquired 
over INR 21 Billion worth 
of operational 
transmission and utility 
solar assets adding to 
our Southern region 
presence, and on the 
other hand we have 
emerged as successful 
bidders in BESS 
development projects 
adding capacity in the 
Northern region, further 
bolstering our growing 
pipeline and expanding 
national footprint. 
Battery Energy Storage (~47 GW) – 
collectively demanding investments 
of over INR 9 Trillion.
This large-scale opportunity itself 
provides headroom for IndiGrid to 
grow and expand. Channelisation of 
long-term capital available to us, 
coupled with an experience delivery 
team and our reliable network of 
partners, we remain poised to not 
only grow rapidly but remain at the 
forefront in meeting India’s energy 
delivery goals.
EnerGrid – Building the Future of 
Grid Infrastructure
Last year, we launched EnerGrid, a 
dedicated platform formed in 
Introduction Corporate Overview Management Reports Financial Statements
IndiGrid Infrastructure Trust (formerly known as India Grid Trust)
3

focus on creating a uniform 
measurable outcome at the portfolio 
level.
While we continue to invest in safety, 
skill development, and community 
engagement, we are now embedding 
sustainability into core engineering 
and operational workflows – from 
intelligent water usage in solar 
cleaning operations to the adoption 
of responsible waste disposal 
protocols and site-specific 
biodiversity preservation initiatives. 
Newer projects are being designed 
with environmental sensitivity as a 
key input, not a postscript – ensuring 
that landscape impact, material 
circularity, and long-term ecological 
stability are considered from the 
outset.
Our first sustainability report 
published for FY 2024-25 is a step 
forward, we endeavour to benchmark 
and calibrate our impact periodically 
with an aim to create a transparent 
and world class ESG coherent 
platform.
Expanding Our Under-
Construction Footprint
Our development portfolio, which is 
held directly under IndiGrid, has six 
projects under construction 
comprising four greenfield ISTS 
transmission assets and two large-
scale Battery Energy Storage System 
(BESS) projects – each contributing 
to the grid enhancement and 
strengthening, especially delivery of 
round the clock green energy.
On the transmission front, our under-
construction portfolio includes 
projects totalling approximately 504 
circuit kilometres of transmission 
lines and 5,000 MVA of transformation 
capacity, including the recently 
awarded Ratle Kiru Power 
Transmission Limited (RKPTL) – a 
strategically important project 
supporting hydro evacuation from 
Jammu & Kashmir.
In the storage domain, we have built 
a strong foundation with the 
successful commissioning of KBPL. 
With this, and the addition of Gujarat 
BESS Private Limited (GBPL) and 
Rajasthan BESS Private Limited (RBPL) 
both currently under construction, 
IndiGrid’s total BESS portfolio on a 
standalone basis would enhance to 
450 MW/900 MWh. The experience 
and capabilities demonstrated in the 
timely and safe delivery of KBPL 
provide us with strong conviction and 
operational readiness to successfully 
execute the remaining BESS projects. 
In addition to the new projects, we 
have been mandated across our 
existing projects for future expansion. 
With the current development 
pipeline, we now have presence 
across 20 states and 2 union 
territories across India. 
In addition to the assets under 
construction in IndiGrid, EnerGrid has 
successfully bid for two BESS projects 
in Uttar Pradesh during the current 
half year with estimated capital 
expenditure of ~INR 19 Million.
Robust Performance and 
Distribution Delivery
During H1 FY 2025-26, IndiGrid’s 
financial performance reflected both 
the strength of our core portfolio and 
the prudence of our capital strategy. 
We ended the financial half year with 
an Assets Under Management (AUM) 
of INR 325 Billion, supported by a 
balanced mix of operational 
resilience and disciplined 
reinvestment. Our Net Debt to AUM 
stood at 61.4%, slightly higher than FY 
2024-25 on account of recent 
acquisitions, but still comfortably 
providing us with meaningful 
headroom to pursue growth 
opportunities while maintaining 
financial stability.
Our operating fundamentals 
remained strong – with Revenue from 
Operations and EBITDA at INR 16,666 
Million and INR 14,287 Million 
respectively during H1 FY 2025-26. 
Comparable Net Distributable Cash 
Flow (NDCF), which is our key delivery 
metric, stood at INR 6,491 Million.
Our performance, fuelled by the 
efficiencies we have built into our 
system and processes over the years, 
has helped us consistently provide 
growing returns to our unitholders. 
We had already increased our DPU 
guidance last year by 6.7% to  
INR 16.00 per unit for the current 
financial year 2025-26 and we remain 
on track to deliver the same to our 
unitholders.
Operational Excellence through 
Digitisation and Reliability
Operational excellence remains a 
cornerstone of IndiGrid’s value 
Growth potential in the energy sector is  
unprecedented. With mainstream integration of 
battery storage and ever urgent focus on green 
transition, private investment is warranted more than 
ever. An enormous INR 1.3 Trillion bid pipeline has 
already been identified across battery and 
transmission space alone and is up for bidding in 
near future.
4
Semi Annual Report 2025-26
proposition – not only as a metric of 
performance, but as a philosophy 
embedded across our asset lifecycle. 
Ever since last fiscal, we have 
continued to strengthen system 
availability and reliability through a 
combination of predictive analytics, 
advanced digital platforms, and 
proactive field interventions.
Our proprietary platform, DigiGrid, 
now forms the digital backbone of 
our operations – enabling real-time 
performance monitoring, anomaly 
detection, and remote diagnostics 
across all transmission and solar 
assets. Supported by drone-based 
inspections, robotic solar module 
cleaning, and predictive weather 
intelligence, these interventions have 
allowed us to shift from periodic 
maintenance to condition-based 
upkeep, optimising both reliability 
and cost efficiency.
In the current financial year, we have 
transitioned to a bigger and efficient 
Central Control Room in Noida, 
tracking all our assets remotely, 
complementing our site teams with 
technology and analytics for better 
uptime.
Our availability for the transmission 
system continues to be 99.4%, and we 
continue to make our transmission 
systems more robust by pre-emptive 
upgrades, timely maintenance and 
efficient use of technology. On the 
solar side, we have seen a slight dip in 
performance with CUF slipping to 
22.2%, largely however on account of 
lower irradiation.
Looking Ahead
As India accelerates its clean energy 
transition, the role of infrastructure 
investment platforms is evolving – 
from being passive asset holders to 
becoming active participants in 
building the nation’s energy future. 
IndiGrid is uniquely positioned to 
contribute meaningfully to this shift – 
by mobilising capital efficiently, 
operating with accountability, and 
moving to adjacencies in the energy 
value chain.
What differentiates us is a solid 
financial platform, coupled with years 
of operational experience across 
geographical regions in the country. 
Our stakeholder relationships have 
helped us stay competitive and 
relevant with changing competitive 
environment. While we gradually 
transitioned to under construction in 
transmission over the past few years 
on the back of our hands-on team, 
being the pioneers in standalone 
BESS development has put us in good 
stead to capture the next set of 
opportunities in this space.
The key to our sustainable growth 
pursuit remains in us being integrated 
throughout the power value chain 
and mitigate risks with our onsite 
presence, a key to picking up 
challenges and addressing them 
ahead of time. Expansion with value 
creation continues to be our theme. 
We envisage that the national grid 
will not only grow at an unprecedented 
rate over the next decade but will 
integrate green energy faster across 
multiple use cases. 
There is enough and more opportunity  
to scale our portfolio through 
disciplined acquisitions and timely 
project commissioning. Through 
EnerGrid, we are creating greater 
visibility into our future growth 
pipeline by actively participating in 
the development of transmission and 
storage projects that align with the 
sector’s evolving needs. And above 
all, we remain committed to delivering 
stable, growing distributions 
underpinned by sound governance 
and a forward-looking strategy.
As we look to the future, we beckon 
your unwavering support for the next 
phase of our growth which has been 
a guiding light for our journey so far. 
We remain committed to creating 
more value for our unitholders, and 
making energy transition for the 
country more realizable and more 
affordable going forward.
Warm regards,
Harsh Shah 
Managing Director

IndiGrid - India’s First and Largest 
Publicly Listed Power Sector 
Infrastructure Investment 
Trust (InvIT)
IndiGrid is India’s first and largest publicly listed power sector Infrastructure 
Investment Trust (InvIT). IndiGrid was formed in 2016 with the goal of 
democratising ownership of power infrastructure in India and providing 
reliable electricity to all. Nine years ago, we embarked on this growth 
journey, built upon solid fundamentals of transparency, governance, and 
sustainability to provide superior risk-adjusted returns to unitholders by 
generating predictable, AAA-rated cash flows from our portfolio assets.

Over the past nine transformative years, 
IndiGrid has grown from a two-asset 
entity into a diversified infrastructure 
platform with 17 operational power 
transmission projects, 19 solar 
generation projects, and the recently 
added Battery Energy Storage System 
(BESS) after the commissioning of 
Kilokari BESS Private Limited (KBPL) — our 
first commercial BESS endeavour.
Our entry into the under-construction 
space began in 2021 with Kallam 
Transmission Limited — our first 
greenfield project. Today, IndiGrid’s 
8x Increase in Assets 
Under Management 
development portfolio comprises 
four under-construction transmission 
projects and two BESS projects, 
reflecting our growing capabilities in 
executing complex infrastructure.
Our execution strength is underscored 
by the successful commissioning 
of Kallam and KBPL, along with four 
augmentation projects completed 
under the RTM framework.
Reinforcing our agility and forward-
looking approach, we launched 
EnerGrid, a dedicated platform to

IndiGrid Infrastructure Trust (formerly known as India Grid Trust)
Balanced Strategy for  
Long-Term Value Creation 
IndiGrid’s key strategies have been developed around our core pillars underpinning 
the strategic aspects of our business and intended to build a resilient and responsible 
organisation. IndiGrid’s main objective is to continue to ensure transmission of reliable 
power to all while delivering superior risk-adjusted total returns to unitholders.
At IndiGrid, our key strategy is to achieve our stated objectives and ensure the organisation is on the course of long-term, 
sustainable, and responsible growth. Owing to our resilient business model, we are growing continually and providing superior 
risk-adjusted returns to unitholders. The Trust is enabling this by investing in long-term, stable, and cash-generating power 
transmission and solar assets.
Portfolio Strategy 
  Focus on maintaining stable 
operations for predictable and 
sustainable distribution while 
looking for value-accretive 
acquisitions
  Greenfield Development:
   Execution of augmentation 
work in existing 
transmission projects 
as well as the 4 new 
transmission projects won
   Execution of BESS projects in 
Gujarat and Rajasthan 
  Proactively participating 
in synergistic greenfield 
opportunities, along with 
EnerGrid, across power 
transmission and BESS 
  Deliver on the DPU guidance 
of INR 16.00 for FY 2025-26, 
supported by disciplined capital 
deployment 
  Optimise interest costs and 
tenor profile for upcoming 
acquisitions
  Maintain prudent leverage 
with sufficient headroom to 
enable organic and inorganic 
growth

IndiGrid Investment Managers Limited 
(IIML)
IndiGrid Investment Managers Limited (IIML) is the 
Investment Manager for IndiGrid. The Investment 
Manager is responsible for the operations pertaining 
to the Trust, such as distribution of cash flows, and 
acquisition/divestment of assets, among others.
IIML executed Investment Management Agreement 
with IndiGrid on November 10, 2016, as amended and 
restated from time to time. As per the provisions 
of the Investment Management Agreement, IIML is 
empowered to: 
 Take all decisions in relation to the management 
and administration of IndiGrid’s assets and 
investments 
 Oversee the activities of the Project Manager in 
terms of the InvIT Regulations and applicable law
 Issue and allot units, accept subscriptions to units 
of IndiGrid and issue, transfer units to unitholders 
or other such people, and undertake all related 
activities
 Engage teams for asset management, M&A, 
capital raising, compliance, engineering and 
finance & accounting
 As on date, KKR owns 100% stake in IIML. 
Esoteric II Pte. Limited (KKR)
Esoteric II Pte. Ltd., an affiliate of KKR, is a sponsor for 
IndiGrid. In the 3rd Annual General Meeting of IndiGrid held 
on September 28, 2020, the unitholders approved the 
induction of Esoteric II Pte. Ltd. as a sponsor (as defined 
under the InvIT Regulations) by a special majority (>75% 
voting). This move marked an extension of IndiGrid’s 
strategic relationship with KKR and is expected to expand 
IndiGrid’s access to long-term capital. KKR’s induction 
has allowed the Trust to leverage KKR’s global experience 
of investment management, along with enhancing its 
corporate governance standards in line with global 
standards. KKR had invested in IndiGrid in May 2019 and 
held 21.2% in the platform as on March 31, 2024. During H1  
FY 2024-25, KKR successfully concluded an offer-for-sale 
process to bring their unitholding down to 3.85% as on 
September 30, 2024. Furthermore, post the conclusion 
of the last round of equity raise in October 2024 through 
preferential issuance of units, KKR’s unitholding reduced 
to 3.61%. In December 2024, KKR sold approximately 
2.41% units that reduced their holding to 1.2% as on date. 
Separately, KKR owns 100% stake in IndiGrid Investment 
Managers Limited (IIML), the Investment Manager of 
IndiGrid.

Mr. Sanil C. Namboodiripad joined IndiGrid 
as Chief Operating Officer on May 26, 2025, 
and leads operations across the InvIT’s diverse 
asset base, including extra high voltage (EHV) 
transmission lines, substations, solar power 
plants, and battery energy storage systems 
(BESS) – spanning both operational and under-
construction projects.
With over 35 years of extensive experience in the 
Indian power sector, Sanil has held leadership 
positions across generation and transmission 
domains, with deep expertise in O&M, asset 
management, and operational strategy. He 
began his career with NTPC, serving 18 years 
at key gas-based projects like Kawas and 
Dabhol. He then held senior roles at Reliance 
Power, Sterlite Power, and Adani Transmission, 
where he managed pan-India portfolios of EHV 
transmission assets, including 25 substations 
and over 11,000 circuit kms of transmission lines 
with HVDC systems.
Most recently, Sanil served as Managing Director 
at ONGC Tripura Power Company (OTPC), a joint 
venture of ONGC, GAIL, and the Government 
of Tripura. Under his leadership, OTPC not only 
operated a critical 726 MW combined cycle 
power plant but also diversified into wind and 
battery storage—developing a 200 MW wind 
project in Odisha and forming a JV to set up 250 
MW/500 MWh BESS in Assam.
Sanil holds a B.Tech in Electrical & Electronics 
Engineering and an MBA in Finance. He is a 
Chartered Engineer and Fellow of the Institution of 
Engineers (India), and a registered Independent 
Director, with global affiliations in engineering 
asset management.

IndiGrid Infrastructure Trust (formerly known as India Grid Trust)IndiGrid Infrastructure Trust (formerly known as India Grid Trust)
Our Asset 
Portfolio 
In the nine eventful years of our existence, we have come a long way. At the time of 
its Initial Public Offering, IndiGrid’s portfolio consisted of 2 transmission assets and 
an AUM of INR 37 Billion. As of the end of H1 FY 2025 26, IndiGrid’s portfolio consists of 
45 assets across three sub-segments, transmission, solar generation, and battery 
storage, worth an AUM of INR 325 Billion, a growth of 8x achieved through a CAGR of 
~30%.
Long-Term Agreements 
IndiGrid’s portfolio is spread across 20 states and 2 union territories of the country. Our assets are located in strategically 
important areas for solar generation, storage and transmission connectivity. 
For all our assets (operational and under-construction) we have long-terms agreements in place with central and other 
reputed counterparties. After completion of the agreement tenures, IndiGrid can apply to the relevant counterparty for 
extension if not unilaterally extended by them.

Semi Annual Report 2025-26
Operational 
Maintenance Needs 
and End-of-Agreement 
Scenarios
Transmission 
Once a transmission project has been 
commissioned, it requires relatively 
low levels of expenditure to operate 
and maintain, which means that the 
InvIT will have the benefit of owning 
a critical asset without incurring 
significant operational costs, leading 
to a superior EBITDA profile of over 
~90%. 
The asset is eligible for 100% of its tariff 
as long as the transmission line has 
been available for 98% of the time 
period. 
In terms of the technical life, a 
transmission asset enjoys a longer 
asset life of ~50 years as compared 
to other infrastructure projects. 
The transmission lines of IndiGrid’s 
portfolio assets are predominantly 
located in areas where developing 
alternate lines may be challenging 
due to the terrain, challenges in 
obtaining rights of way, limited 
corridors and high construction 
costs. This puts IndiGrid in an 
advantageous position to capitalise 
on the opportunities to increase our 
power transmission capacity through 
the same corridor by upgrading our 
existing systems. 
Solar 
Solar power projects offer stable 
long-term cash flows backed by 
Power Purchase Agreements (PPAs) 
with creditworthy off-takers. These 
contracts typically span 20–25 
years, ensuring predictable revenue 
visibility. After commissioning, solar 
assets have relatively low operating 
costs, with minimal fuel or variable 
input dependencies. This supports a 
robust EBITDA margin of ~80–85%.
The technical life of a solar project 
is typically ~25 years, with potential 
to extend through repowering or 
technical upgrades. IndiGrid’s solar 
assets are strategically located in 
high solar irradiance zones, enabling 
efficient generation. With growing 
grid-integration of renewables and 
supportive policy mechanisms. 
IndiGrid is well-positioned to benefit 
from long-term tailwinds in the 
renewable energy sector.
Battery Energy Storage Systems 
Battery Energy Storage Systems 
(BESS) are emerging as a vital 
enabler of grid stability, renewable 
integration, and peak demand 
management. All of IndiGrid’s BESS 
projects have secured 12-year Battery 
Energy Storage Purchase Agreements 
(BESPAs) with utilities, under which 
the tariff is pre-determined at the 
time of bidding and is payable as 
long as the system remains available 
for use by the off-taker – following 
a structure similar to transmission 
service agreements.
While actual long-term O&M lifecycle 
benchmarks are still evolving due to 
the nascent nature of the technology, 
BESS projects generally require 
relatively low maintenance, hence 
translating into an anticipated 
superior EBITDA profile of ~90%. 
The typical technical life of a BESS 
asset is ~15 years, with potential for 
system augmentation. IndiGrid’s 
assets are strategically located to 
cater to high-demand urban centres, 
providing strong value potential 
through grid services, policy-
backed revenue security, and future 
expansion optionality.

IndiGrid Infrastructure Trust (formerly known as India Grid Trust)
BHOPAL-DHULE TRANSMISSION PROJECT (BDTCL)
BDTCL was incorporated on September 08, 2009. 
BDTCL entered into a TSA on December 07, 2010 
with LTTCs. The BDTCL project was awarded to IGL 
(erstwhile Sterlite Grid 1 Limited) by the Ministry of 
Power on January 31, 2011 for a 35-year period from 
the scheduled commercial operation date, on a 
Build, Own, Operate and Maintain (BOOM) basis. 
We acquired BDTCL from the Sterlite Sponsor in 
May 2017. The BDTCL project is part of the system 
strengthening scheme of the western region and 
facilitates the transfer of up to 5,000 MW of electricity 
from the coal belt in the East, to the energy deficient 
regions of western and northern India. BDTCL owns 
943 ckms of transmission lines covering six elements 
and two substations with 2x1,500 MVA capacity each. 
BDTCL operates six EHV overhead transmission lines 
comprising four 765 kV Single Circuit and two 400 
kV Double Circuit lines commissioned to strengthen 
the transmission system in the states of Madhya 
Pradesh, Maharashtra, and Gujarat. There are also 
two 765/400 kV substations at Bhopal (Madhya 
Pradesh) and Dhule (Maharashtra).

JABALPUR TRANSMISSION PROJECT (JTCL)
JTCL was incorporated on September 08, 2009. JTCL 
entered into a TSA with LTTCs on December 1, 2010 
and a TSA on November 12, 2013 with PGCIL (together 
JTCL TSAs). The JTCL project was awarded to IGL 
(erstwhile Sterlite Grid 1 Limited) by the Ministry of 
Power on January 19, 2011 for a 35-year period from 
the scheduled commercial operation date, on a 
build-own-operate-maintain (BOOM) basis. We 
acquired JTCL from our Sterlite Sponsor on May 30, 
2017.
JTCL is a part of the system strengthening common 
for the Western Region and the Northern Region. The 
project alleviates transmission capacity bottlenecks 
and expands the reliability and stability of the power 
grid in Western and Northern India by providing 
open access to transmit power from independent 
power projects in the eastern region of India. The 
corridors, thus, created are crucial links, on the basis 
of which the Central Transmission Utility has entered 
long-term open-access agreements with several 
generation companies in the Eastern Region.
JTCL operates two EHV overhead transmission lines 
of ~995 ckms in Chhattisgarh and Madhya Pradesh 
comprising one 765 kV double circuit line of 759 ckms 
from Jabalpur (Madhya Pradesh) to Dharamjaigarh 
(Chhattisgarh) and one 765 kV single circuit line of 
235 ckms from Jabalpur to Bina in Madhya Pradesh.

RAPP TRANSMISSION PROJECT (RTCL)
Current Status: As of September 30, 2025, RTCL TSA had a remaining term of ~25.5 years.
RTCL was incorporated on December 20, 2012 and 
RTCL entered a TSA (the RTCL TSA) with LTTCs on 
July 24, 2013. The RTCL project was awarded by the 
Ministry of Power on September 17, 2013, for a 35-year 
period from the scheduled commercial operation 
date on a BOOM basis. We acquired RTCL from our 
Sterlite Sponsor on February 14, 2018.
RTCL strengthens the transmission capability 
between the northern and western sectors of India’s 
power grid by evacuating electricity from an atomic 
power plant near Kota in Rajasthan to central 
Madhya Pradesh. The project was set up to transfer 
power from the atomic power plant near Kota 
(Rawalbhata) in Rajasthan to Shujalpur in Madhya 
Pradesh to provide the path for the evacuation of 
electricity generated at RAPP-7 and 8. The project 
involves operation of one 400 kV Double Circuit 
transmission line stretching over 400 ckms. RTCL 
acts as an interregional link between the Northern 
and western region by helping in evacuation of 
power from the power complex, even in case of any 
grid constraints in the northern region.

PURULIA and KHARAGPUR TRANSMISSION PROJECT (PKTCL)
PKTCL was incorporated on December 15, 2012, and

MAHESHWARAM TRANSMISSION PROJECT (MTL)
Current Status: As of September 30, 2025, MTL TSA had a remaining term of ~27.5 years.
MTL was incorporated on August 14, 2014 and entered 
into a TSA (the MTL TSA) with LTTCs on June 10, 2015. 
The MTL project was awarded by the Ministry of 
Power on July 21, 2015 for a 35-year period from the 
scheduled commercial operation date. The Project 
was awarded on BOOM basis. We acquired 49% of 
MTL from the Sterlite Sponsor in February 2018.
MTL constitutes a key component in enabling the 
southern region of India to draw more power from 
the rest of the grid and seeks to address the issue 
of power stability in Southern India. The improved 
grid connectivity has facilitated power procurement 
from the Inter-State Transmission System (ISTS) 
network to the beneficiary states Telangana, Tamil 
Nadu, Seemandhra, and Karnataka to meet their 
electricity demands. MTL operates two EHV overhead 
transmission lines with a total circuit length of 
approximately 475 ckms in the state of Telangana.

NRSS XXIX TRANSMISSION PROJECT (NTL)
Current Status:  As of September 30, 2025, NTL TSA had a remaining term of ~28 years.
NRSS XXIX Transmission Limited (NTL) was 
incorporated on July 29, 2013, and entered into a TSA 
on January 02, 2014, with LTTCs. The NTL project is held 
by IGL 1 and was awarded by the Ministry of Power 
on a perpetual ownership basis with a TSA term of 
35 years from the scheduled commercial operation 
date. We acquired NTL from Sterlite Sponsor on June 
04, 2019.
NTL is one of the largest private sector transmission 
project awarded in the country. The project is 
extremely critical to meet the power requirements 
of Jammu & Kashmir. The NTL project is expected to 
deliver over 2,000 MW of electricity from Punjab to the 
Kashmir Valley by strengthening the transmission 
system in the states of Jammu and Kashmir and 
Punjab. NTL consists of three 400 kV double circuit 
transmission lines and one 400/220 kV GIS substation.

EAST-NORTH INTERCONNECTION PROJECT (ENICL)
Current Status:  As of September 30, 2025, ENICL TSA had remaining term of ~10 years.
East-North Interconnection Company Limited (ENICL) 
was incorporated on February 1, 2007. ENICL entered 
into a TSA on August 6, 2009 with LTTCs. The ENICL 
project was awarded by the Ministry of Power on a 
perpetual ownership-basis with a TSA term of 25 
years from the date of issue of the licence by CERC. 
We acquired ENICL from the Sterlite Sponsor in May 
2020.
The project addresses the critical issue of the 
power shortfall during non-Monsoon months, 
thereby bringing significant relief to the people of 
Assam. ENICL operates two 400 kV Double Circuit 
transmission lines of 896 ckms through challenging 
terrain in the States of Assam, West Bengal, and 
Bihar. Commonly referred to as the Siliguri Corridor 
or the Chicken’s Neck, the peculiarity of this stretch 
is that it is the only land route connecting mainland 
India with North-East India making it critical from an 
inter-region power transfer point of view.

GURGAON-PALWAL TRANSMISSION PROJECT (GPTL)
Gurgaon-Palwal Transmission Limited (GPTL) was 
incorporated on October 26, 2015. GPTL entered into 
a TSA on March 04, 2016, with LTTCs. GPTL project 
was awarded to SGL4 by the Ministry of Power on 
a perpetual ownership basis with a TSA term of 35 
years from the scheduled commercial operation 
date. We acquired 100% economic ownership of GPTL 
from Sterlite Sponsor in August 2020.
GPTL is part of Inter State Transmission Scheme 
(ISTS) network and consists of three gas-insulated 
substations (GIS) with a total transformation 
capacity of 3,000 MVA and ~273 circuit kilometres 
of 400 KV transmission lines. The project is first-of-
its-kind, vertically mounted GIS framework with a 
substantial focus on ESG aspects. It is a strategic 
asset for ensuring reliable power supply in the region 
which may reduce carbon emissions by reducing 
dependence on DG sets. The land requirement 
for this project is also substantially reduced with 
innovatively designed vertical GIS substations and 
monopole towers with micro-piling.

PARBATI KOLDAM TRANSMISSION PROJECT (PrKTCL)
Parbati Koldam Transmission Company Limited 
(‘PrKTCL’) is IndiGrid’s first cost-plus regulated asset. 
PrKTCL is an inter-state operational asset situated in 
Himachal Pradesh and Punjab, and was awarded on 
a Build, Own, Operate (‘BOO’) basis for the transfer 
of electricity from Parbati II and Koldam HEPs in 
Himachal to Ludhiana in Punjab. The Project was a 
joint venture between Reliance Infrastructure and 
Power Grid. PrKTCL was incorporated on September 
2, 2002. PrKTCL entered into various long-term Bulk 
Power Agreement (BPTA) on March 4, 2010. The 
Project was awarded as a cost-plus project with a 
guaranteed ROE of 15.5% on the approved equity 
base. In January 2020, we completed the acquisition 
of 74% of the equity shares of PrKTCL from Reliance 
Infrastructure Limited. PrKTCL is now held as a joint 
venture between IndiGrid (74%) and Power Grid 
Corporation of India Limited (26%).
PrKTCL operates two transmission lines, subdivided 
into various revenue-generating elements, with 
a total circuit length of approximately 458 ckms 
of 400 kV transmission lines and substations. This 
transmission project is of very strategic importance 
and has been constructed for evacuation of the 
power generated from Hydro-Electric Projects (HEPs) 
of 2,220 MW which is utilised by northern region states 
of Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan, Punjab, Haryana, Jammu 
& Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Delhi, Chandigarh, 
and Uttarakhand.

JAISALMER URJA VI PRIVATE LIMITED (FORMERLY KNOWN AS 
RENEW SOLAR URJA PRIVATE LIMITED, OR RSUPL)
IndiGrid consummated the acquisition of JUPL 
during the last quarter of FY 2023-24. Operational 
since December 2021, JUPL is a 300 MW (AC) solar 
generation asset located in the high irradiation 
region of Jaisalmer, Rajasthan, operating under a 
25-year PPA with the Solar Energy Corporation of 
India (SECI) to sell power generated at a tariff of  
INR 2.71 per unit. 
JUPL is a strategic addition to IndiGrid’s portfolio as it 
fits well with IndiGrid’s strategy of holding operational 
and revenue generating assets till maturity. Now 
in the portfolio, JUPL is the largest solar generation 
capacity project located at a single site. With this 
acquisition, IndiGrid also crossed the ~1.1 GW mark for 
its peak solar capacity.
Current Status: As of September 30, 2025, JUPL PPA had a remaining term of ~21 years.

67
IndiGrid Infrastructure Trust (formerly known as India Grid Trust)
KILOKARI BESS PRIVATE LIMITED (KBPL)
Kilokari BESS Private Limited project was awarded 
to IndiGrid in October 2023 by BSES Rajdhani Power 
Limited (BRPL) to Design, Supply, Testing, Installation, 
Commissioning, Operation and Maintenance of 20 
MW/40 MWh Battery Energy Storage System in Delhi. 
The KBPL project was envisaged on a build, own, 
operate and transfer (BOOT) basis for a period of 
12 years and was bid out through the tariff-based 
competitive bidding (TBCB) mechanism.
The Battery Energy Storage Service Agreement 
(BESSA) was signed in December 2023 for a 
period of 12 years from the date of commissioning.  
Co-located with a legacy substation in a densely 
populated area of South Delhi, the project execution 
team overcame a multitude of challenges and 
commissioned the project in record time by  
March 31, 2025. 
KBPL has been developed in collaboration with 
AmpereHour Energy and received concessional 
funding from Global Energy Alliance for People and 
Planet (GEAPP).

IndiGrid Infrastructure Trust (formerly known as India Grid Trust)
Management 
Discussion and 
Analysis
Management 
Discussion and 
Analysis
Economic Updates and Outlook
Global Economy
The global economy is gradually 
stabilising, continuing the slow 
recovery with major economies 
managing a soft landing after a 
period of policy tightening. Growth 
momentum has remained moderate 
but resilient, supported by improving 
financial conditions, easing supply 
constraints, and a rebound in cross-
border trade and investment.
Global output is projected to expand 
by around 3.1% in 2026, slightly 
below the pre-pandemic average 
but indicative of a more balanced 
and sustained recovery. Advanced 
economies are growing at a slower 
yet stable pace, with aggregate 
expansion estimated at 1.6%. In 
the United States, steady labour-
market strength and targeted fiscal 
measures are expected to support 
growth of 2.0%, even as inflation 
stays marginally above the target 
range. The Euro Area is projected to 
expand by 1.2%, driven by modest 
improvements in external demand, 
with Germany and France growing 
by 0.9% and 1.0%, respectively. Japan 
is expected to post 0.5% growth, 
constrained by demographic

pressures, while the United Kingdom 
and Canada are anticipated 
to record moderate recoveries, 
reflecting normalised consumption 
and investment trends.
Among emerging and developing 
economies, growth remains the key 
driver of global expansion, projected 
at 4.0%. India continues to lead with an 
expected growth of 6.4%, supported 
by robust domestic demand, policy-

and a strong manufacturing push. 
China is projected to grow by 4.2%, 
aided by export resilience and credit

buoyed by regional trade recovery 
and supply-chain diversification. 
Elsewhere, Sub-Saharan Africa is 
anticipated to expand by 4.3%, the

Latin America and the Caribbean by 
2.4%, and emerging and developing 
Europe by 2.2%.
Global inflation is expected to ease 
further to 3.6% in 2026, supported by 
stabilising energy and commodity 
prices, improved supply dynamics, 
and sustained monetary discipline. 
While advanced economies are 
approaching their inflation targets, 
several emerging markets continue 
to face elevated food and fuel prices. 
Central banks are likely to maintain 
a cautious policy stance—balancing 
growth support with price stability—
until inflation expectations are firmly 
anchored.
Outlook
Looking ahead, the global economic 
outlook remains cautiously 
optimistic, though risks persist. Key 
downside factors include renewed 
geopolitical tensions, persistent 
trade fragmentation, sovereign-
debt vulnerabilities in developing 
economies, and climate-related 
disruptions that could affect supply 
chains and commodity markets. 
Conversely, successful trade 
negotiations, progress in structural 
reforms, and calibrated fiscal and 
monetary actions could reinforce 
global growth prospects. Overall, 
the world economy appears to 
be entering a phase of measured 
consolidation, marked by resilience, 
policy prudence, and a gradual 
strengthening of macroeconomic 
fundamentals.

Indian Economy
India’s economy continued to demonstrate strong momentum in FY 2024-25, 
remaining the world’s fastest-growing major economy. The Reserve Bank of India 
(RBI) recently revised its GDP growth forecast upwards to 6.8% in FY 2025-26, 
reflecting robust domestic fundamentals, improved macroeconomic stability, 
and a resilient policy environment that has effectively cushioned the impact of 
global trade disruptions.
Supported by steady consumption demand, rural recovery, and healthy 
investment activity, the Indian economy is consolidating its pre-pandemic 
growth trajectory. Favourable monsoon conditions, declining inflation, and stable 
crude oil prices (USD 65–70 per barrel) have strengthened purchasing power and 
improved household sentiment. Lower input costs and moderating interest rates 
are also expected to spur private investment through the second half of the year.

India’s ongoing infrastructure expansion continues to act as a catalyst for 
broader economic growth. Public capital expenditure by the Central and State 
Governments rose over 50% year-on-year in the first two months of FY 2025-26, 
reaffirming policy continuity towards long-term capacity building.
Meanwhile, services exports, accounting for nearly 47% of total exports, are 
providing a stable buffer against goods trade volatility amid global tariff 
realignments. Healthy external markers of current account deficit near 1% of 
GDP and foreign exchange reserves exceeding USD 700 Billion, further reinforce 
macroeconomic strength.
Outlook
The outlook for FY 2025–26 remains 
positive, supported by resilient 
domestic demand, moderating 
inflation, and policy tailwinds. 
According to CRISIL and the World 
Bank, India’s GDP is expected to grow 
between 6.5% and 6.8%, maintaining 
its global growth leadership. Over 
the medium term, growth will be 
driven by infrastructure investment, 
manufacturing expansion under the 
‘Make in India’ and PLI schemes, and 
an accelerated push towards the 
energy transition.
To sustain this momentum, continued 
focus on structural reforms, regulatory 
simplification, and technology 
adoption will be critical to enhancing 
productivity, attracting long-term 
investment, and strengthening India’s 
ability to navigate an evolving global 
economic landscape.

Powering Sustainable Growth:  
Industry Overview
Electricity: The 
Catalyst of Modern 
Economic Growth
India has achieved remarkable 
progress in fortifying its energy 
ecosystem in recent years, adeptly 
harmonising the imperatives of 
accelerating electricity demand 
and advancing environmental 
sustainability. As highlighted by the 
International Energy Agency (IEA), 
emerging and developing economies 
are poised to contribute nearly 85% 
of the global surge in electricity 
demand over the next three years, 
with India emerging as a linchpin 
in this transformation. Propelled by 
robust and sustained economic 
expansion, India is expected to 
witness the fastest growth in 
energy consumption among 
major economies. Consequently, 
its share in global primary energy 
use is projected to double by 2035, 
reflecting the nation’s pivotal role in 
steering the global energy transition.
Amid this transformation, electricity 
stands at the heart of India’s growth 
narrative, serving as the cornerstone 
of modern development. It powers 
industries, drives digital infrastructure, 
and enhances social well-being. 
By fuelling productivity, fostering 
innovation, and improving the quality 
of life across households, enterprises, 
and communities, electricity forms 
the vital link connecting India’s 
economic ambitions with its 
sustainability goals.
In India, electricity demand grew 
by 1.4% year-on-year in the first 
half of 2025, shaped by global 
economic uncertainties affecting 
industrial activity and cooler summer 
temperatures compared to 2024. The 
International Energy Agency (IEA) 
expects demand to pick up in the 
second half, bringing the full-year 
growth to around 4%, slightly slower 
than in 2024 due to milder weather. 
Looking further ahead, India’s 
electricity demand is projected to 
expand at an annual rate of roughly 
6.3–6.6% between 2025 and 2027. 
This acceleration will be driven 
by stronger industrial and service 
sector activity, rising incomes, and 
deeper penetration of appliances 
such as air conditioners, with growth 
particularly pronounced in residential 
and commercial segments as 
consumption patterns evolve.
The multiplier effect of power-
led infrastructure on the broader 
economy is significant. While sector-
specific multipliers for electricity are 
not officially published, infrastructure-
wide estimates often cited in policy 
discourse indicate a ~2.5–3.5x GDP 
multiplier, reflecting strong forward 
and backward linkages across 
construction, steel, cement, logistics, 
and technology. This underscores the 
strategic importance of sustained 
investments across generation, 
transmission, and distribution to 
meet rising demand and strengthen 
long-term energy security.
India’s Power 
Sector Framework
India’s power sector stands out as 
one of the most diversified globally, 
harnessing a wide array of energy 
sources. Traditional fuels such as 
coal, lignite, natural gas, oil, hydro, 
and nuclear coexist with renewable 
and alternative resources, including 
wind, solar, agricultural residues, and 
municipal waste. The sector is in the 
midst of a profound transformation, 
driven by four key pillars: 
Decarbonisation, Decentralisation, 
Digitalisation, and Democratisation. 
https://www.pib.gov.in/PressNoteDetails.aspx?NoteId=154717&ModuleId=3
https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/india/indias-electricity-demand-to-rise-4-pc-in-2025-iea/articleshow/122998337.cms
https://static.pib.gov.in/WriteReadData/specificdocs/documents/2025/jun/doc2025622575501.pdf)
Sources
These fundamental changes are 
reshaping the way India produces, 
transmits, and utilises electricity, 
paving the way for a cleaner, more 
intelligent, and inclusive energy 
ecosystem.
The sector is organised into three core 
segments: generation, transmission, 
and distribution.
 Generation entails the production 
of electricity at power plants 
using various energy inputs and 
technologies
 Transmission involves the 
high-voltage conveyance of 
bulk electricity from generation 
facilities to distribution substations 
via the national grid
 Distribution: represents the final 
stage, channelling electricity 
from substations to end users 
through lower-voltage networks, 
functioning as the retail interface 
that delivers power directly to 
households, businesses, and 
communities
The entire framework operates under 
the supervision of both Central and 
State regulators and is continually 
strengthened by progressive policies. 
These reforms aim to enhance 
efficiency, promote transparency, 
attract private investment, and 
support a more resilient and future-
ready electricity ecosystem.
Currently, India’s power sector 
is undergoing a profound 
transformation guided by four 
key pillars: Decarbonisation, 
Decentralisation, Digitalisation, and 
Democratisation. These structural 
shifts are redefining how electricity 
is produced, transmitted, and 
consumed, setting the stage for a 
cleaner, smarter, and more inclusive 
energy ecosystem.

In August 2025, India set a new milestone in electricity demand, with peak 
consumption reaching 229,715 MW and a total supply of 150,000 Million units 
(MU) for the month, according to the National Load Despatch Centre (NLDC). The 
average peak demand during this period stood at 215,314 MW, while the average 
daily energy supplied was approximately 4,854 MU, reflecting a notable rise in 
electricity consumption driven by seasonal needs and sustained economic 
activity.

*RES: Renewable energy sources comprise solar, wind, small hydro, and biomass, among others.
As of September 30, 2025, India’s total installed power generation capacity has 
reached over 500 GW, with non-fossil fuel sources contributing 256 GW, or 51.1% 
of the total, achieving the clean energy milestone five years ahead of the target 
set under its Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) to the Paris Agreement. 
This includes 247.3 GW from renewable sources and 8.8 GW from nuclear power, 
while the remaining 244.8 GW comes from thermal generation. 
This landmark achievement highlights India’s strong commitment to climate 
action and sustainable development and sets a global benchmark for clean 
energy growth. It reflects a rapidly accelerating transition towards green energy, 
showing that the country’s move away from fossil fuels is both substantial and on 
a forward-looking trajectory.
Despite this increase, India’s peak 
power demand for the summer fell 
short of earlier projections. Estimates 
for summer 2025 had anticipated a 
peak of 277 GW, but the actual record 
peak occurred at 242.77 GW in June. 
In comparison, the highest supply 
met in August was 229.71 GW, up from 
216.47 GW in August 2024, yet still 
below the all-time high of 250 GW 
recorded in May 2024. The moderation 
in demand relative to projections was 
largely influenced by above-average 
monsoon rainfall, which tempered 
electricity consumption across the 
country.
The Central Electricity Authority 
(CEA) and NEP 2024–47 project that 
India’s peak electricity demand could 
surge to 817 GW by 2047, more than 
three times current levels. Meeting 
this soaring demand necessitates 
a transformative overhaul across 
the entire power ecosystem - from 
generation to transmission and 
distribution. This includes accelerated 
deployment of renewable energy, 
advanced energy storage solutions, 
smart grid technologies, and 
comprehensive modernisation of 
transmission networks to ensure a 
resilient, flexible, and future-ready 
electricity infrastructure.

Power Generation: Greening the 
Grid with Depth and Discipline
India’s total power generation 
reached 799 Billion units (BU) in 
August 2025, reflecting a mix that 
is both diverse and evolving. Coal 
remained the dominant source, 
contributing 539.33 BU or 67.5% of the 
total output. Despite a growing focus 
on cleaner energy, coal continues 
to underpin the electricity system, 
providing steady and dependable 
baseload power. Its dominance 
highlights the ongoing challenge 
of balancing energy security with 
environmental sustainability.
Power from oil and gas accounted 
for 13.57 BU, or 1.7%, playing a niche 
role in meeting peak demand and 
supporting grid stability, though its 
expansion is limited by high fuel 
costs and constrained domestic 
supply. Nuclear energy added 23.2 
BU, or 2.9%, offering a reliable, low-
carbon alternative that diversifies the 
energy mix. Its contribution is modest 
but strategic, with future growth 
expected as new capacity comes 
online.
Renewables are making an 
increasingly noticeable impact, 
collectively contributing around 
28% of total generation. Hydro 
power generated 84.84 BU, or 10.6%, 
providing crucial flexibility for peak 
loads and seasonal variability. Wind 
power contributed 60.65 BU, or 
7.6%, remaining an essential pillar 
of clean energy production. Solar 
energy reached 67.81 BU, or 8.5%, 
reflecting rapid capacity additions 
and the success of policy initiatives. 
Smaller contributions came from 
biopower (4.75 BU; 0.6%) and small 
hydro (4.86 BU; 0.6%), which play a 
vital role in decentralised and rural 
electrification.
Overall, thermal sources, including 
coal, oil, and gas accounted for 
roughly 69% of total generation, 
renewables about 28%, and nuclear 
energy 3%. The pattern indicates 
a steady transition: while coal 
continues to anchor the system, 
renewable energy is steadily gaining 
ground. Solar and wind growth 
reflects technological progress, 
supportive policies, and declining 
costs, positioning India as a global 
leader in clean energy adoption.
This generation profile underscores 
a transformative phase in India’s 
energy sector. Efforts to modernise 
the grid, integrate storage 
solutions, and enhance flexibility in 
conventional plants will be key to 
accommodating rising renewable 
shares while ensuring a reliable and 
resilient electricity supply.
The Indian Government has rolled 
out a series of strategic initiatives to 
accelerate power generation and 
drive the energy transition. Central 
to these efforts is the expansion of 
renewable energy capacity, with 
a target of 500 GW of non-fossil 
fuel power by 2030, backed by 
programmes such as the Production-
Linked Incentive (PLI) schemes for 
solar modules, battery storage, and 
green hydrogen.
In parallel, nuclear energy is slated 
to reach 100 GW by 2047, supported 
by significant investments in Small 
Modular Reactors (SMRs). The 
government is also focussing on rural 
electrification, grid modernisation, 
and distribution reforms to enhance 
efficiency, reliability, and accessibility 
across the country.
Outlook
India’s power sector is entering 
a growth-oriented phase, driven 
by a major shift towards non-
fossil fuel sources, targeting 
500 GW of renewable capacity by 
2030. Reducing crude oil import 
dependency, currently around 85%, 
remains a strategic priority, with 
incentives for domestic exploration, 
biofuels, and hydrogen. Renewables, 
energy storage, and green hydrogen 
are expected to expand further 
through industrial and international 
collaborations, though demand-side 
challenges must be addressed.
Coal continues to anchor the energy 
mix, while nuclear energy, including 
Bharat Small Reactors (BSRs), is 
emerging as a low-carbon option. 
Oil and gas dynamics, influenced by 
global supply constraints and US LNG 
exports, are shaping India’s energy 
strategy, including plans for one 
Million barrels per day of new refining 
capacity by 2030.
Technological adoption—AI, 
digitalisation, smart meters—will 
enhance efficiency and planning, 
while regulatory reforms, such as the 
Oilfields Regulation & Development 
Act (ORDA) and MoPNG initiatives, 
aim to strengthen energy security, 
governance, and investment ease.

Power Transmission: Strengthening 
the Backbone of Energy Security
India’s electricity transmission 
system forms the critical backbone 
of the nation’s power infrastructure, 
enabling the smooth flow of 
electricity from generation centres 
to consumers across vast distances. 
This network not only ensures reliable 
power supply but also plays a 
pivotal role in integrating renewable 
energy, maintaining grid stability, 
and meeting the growing electricity 
demand of both urban and rural 
areas. Continuous expansion and 
modernisation of transmission 
lines are key to supporting India’s 
economic growth and energy 
transition.
As per NITI Aayog, as of September 
2025, India’s transmission network 
spans a total of 4,96,372 circuit 
kilometres (cKM), reflecting the 
country’s extensive electricity 
infrastructure. Of this, central 
transmission lines account for 
1,86,322 cKM, forming the backbone 
for inter-state power transfer and 
ensuring reliable long-distance 
electricity flow. State transmission 
lines contribute 2,66,542 cKM, 
playing a critical role in distributing 
power within states and connecting 
regional generation sources to local 
demand centres. Joint venture and 
private transmission lines make 
up 43,508 cKM, highlighting the 
increasing participation of private 
and collaborative ventures in 
strengthening the grid. This expansive 
network supports efficient power 
delivery across India, enabling grid 
stability, integration of renewable 
energy, and meeting the rising 
electricity demand of both urban and 
rural areas.
During the first half of  
FY 2025–26, additional capacity 
was commissioned across major 
Renewable Energy Zones (REZs) 
in Rajasthan, Gujarat, Tamil Nadu, 
Maharashtra, and Karnataka, 
with multiple 400 kV and 765 kV 
corridors under implementation. The 
network composition continues to 
be dominated by 400 kV and 220 kV 
systems, while High-Voltage Direct 
Current (HVDC) corridors of ±800 kV 
and ±500 kV are gaining strategic 
importance for long-distance, high-
efficiency power transfer, particularly 
for renewable evacuation from 
Western clusters.
Technological modernisation 
also advanced during the period. 
Deployment of Phasor Measurement 
Units (PMUs), Wide-Area Monitoring 
Systems (WAMS), and control-centre 
upgrades under CTUIL/POWERGRID 
programmes enhanced grid visibility, 
operational resilience, and real-time 
fault diagnostics.
Private sector participation through 
the TBCB mechanism remained 
strong in H1 FY 2025-26. Entities such 
as POWERGRID and Adani Energy 
Solutions secured or progressed 
multiple inter-state transmission 
projects through competitive 
bidding, reflecting sustained investor 
confidence in the sector.
A major milestone was the 
commissioning of IndiGrid’s 20 MW/40 
MWh standalone Battery Energy 
Storage System (BESS) at Kilokari, 
Delhi, in April 2025, with regulator-
approved tariff. This marks India’s first 
regulated, utility-scale, standalone 
storage asset, providing frequency 
support, congestion management, 
and grid stability at the distribution 
interface.

Strategic priorities during  
H1 FY 2025-26 included:
 Continued rollout of Green Energy 
Corridor (GEC) Phase II across 
states, with expanded 220–400

and underground cabling to

the Butwal–Gorakhpur 400 kV

upgrades under existing 
frameworks
In policy and financing developments, the June 2025 amendment to the Inter-
State Transmission System (ISTS) bidding framework allowed Insurance Surety 
Bonds and Payment-of-Order Instruments as bid security, enhancing flexibility 
in project financing. Additionally, the CEA has begun revising transmission 
plans every six months to better align with renewable growth and evolving grid 
conditions, supporting India’s long-term goal of integrating 600 GW of renewable 
capacity.

Outlook 
For the remainder of FY 2025–26, the transmission sector is expected to maintain strong momentum. Key priorities include 
completing pending Green Energy Corridor Phase II works, accelerating major 765 kV and HVDC corridors linked to renewable 
zones such as Raigarh–Pugalur II, and integrating storage-linked nodes at pooling substations to enhance flexibility. 
Continued policy and investment focus on high-capacity corridors, digital grid technologies, and private sector participation 
will further strengthen the transmission backbone, ensuring reliability, redundancy, and readiness for higher renewable 
penetration.

80 Semi Annual Report 2025-26
Power Distribution: Enabling Last-Mile 
Delivery and Reform
India’s power distribution sector 
is steadily evolving, moving from 
a historically loss-heavy and 
infrastructure-limited system to a 
digitally enabled, performance-
driven, and customer-focused 
network. With universal household 
electrification achieved and 
renewable energy increasingly 
integrated, the sector serves as the 
crucial last-mile link in the electricity 
value chain, ensuring reliable 
supply, operational efficiency, and 
financial stability. Challenges like 
high distribution losses, power theft, 
and stressed utility finances persist, 
but the creation of a unified National 
Grid - connecting regional networks 
through advanced transmission 
technology - enables smooth 
electricity transfer from surplus to 
deficit areas, strengthening both 
reliability and India’s clean energy 
transition.
The sector’s financial performance 
showed continued improvement 
entering FY 2025–26. As of mid-2025, 
aggregate technical and commercial 
(AT&C) losses had declined from 
21.91% in FY 2020-21 to 16.12% in FY 
2023-24, while the Average Cost 
of Supply (ACS)–Average Revenue 
Realised (ARR) gap narrowed from 
INR 0.69/kWh in FY 2020-21 to INR 
0.19/kWh in FY 2023-24. These figures 
reflect better billing efficiency, 
improved subsidy disbursement, 
and stronger collection performance 
under reform-linked programmes. 
The reliability of power supply also 
strengthened. The Ministry of Power’s 
annual review placed urban hours 
of supply (HoS) at 23.53 hours/day, 
while government communication 
cited urban supply at around 23.4 
hours/day and rural supply at about 
22.6 hours/day in 2025, indicative of 
near-universal access and improved 
service delivery.
Reforms under the Revamped 
Distribution Sector Scheme (RDSS) 
continued to drive structural 
improvements. The programme, 
with a total outlay of INR 3,03,758 
Crore from FY 2021–22 to  
FY 2025–26, remains the cornerstone 
for loss reduction, ACS–ARR gap 
narrowing, and quality-of-supply 
enhancement. RDSS is results-linked, 
with funding tied to measurable 
performance metrics, reinforcing 
accountability across utilities. 
Digitalisation also remained central 
to the transformation agenda. Under 
RDSS, 20.33 Crore smart meters were 
sanctioned, of which 2.41 Crore were 
installed as of July 15, 2025, according 
to official data. The National Smart 
Grid Mission dashboard, updated on 
September 30, 2025, provides state-
wise progress snapshots. Deployment 
of smart meters, advanced metering 
infrastructure (AMI), and digital 
billing systems is expected to further 
enhance transparency and loss 
monitoring.
The sector also saw progress in 
rooftop integration and bidirectional 
energy flows through the PM Surya 
Ghar: Muft Bijli Yojana, which has a 
total outlay of INR 75,021 Crore and 
achieved 10.09 Lakhs rooftop solar 
installations by March 10, 2025. This 
initiative is driving household-level 
solar adoption and enabling net 
metering at scale. Financial discipline 
and transparency improved through 
continued enforcement of the 
Electricity (Late Payment Surcharge 
and Related Matters) Rules, 2022, 
along with the 2024 amendments 
issued by the Ministry of Power. In 
parallel, the Electricity Distribution 
(Accounts and Additional Disclosure) 
Rules, 2024 introduced enhanced 
accounting and provisioning 
standards, strengthening fiscal 
accountability and lender confidence.
The 13 th Integrated Rating and 
Ranking Report (July 2025) by PFC 
India reflected continued operational 
improvement, with 40 of 63 DISCOMs 
reporting reduced AT&C losses in FY 
2023–24 and visible progress on cost 
recovery and financial parameters. 
On-ground modernisation during the 
first half of FY 2025–26 included feeder 
modernisation, GIS substations, 
underground cabling, transformer 
upgrades, and loss-reduction works 
under RDSS. These projects are 
enhancing supply reliability and 
preparing networks for rooftop solar, 
EV charging, and distributed storage 
integration.
Despite progress, challenges persist. 
Resistance to prepaid metering and 
tariff rationalisation in some States 
continues to delay uniform adoption 
of reforms. Utilities also face the 
ongoing task of integrating legacy IT 
and operational systems to handle 
growing volumes of AMI data and 
two-way power flows. Cybersecurity 
frameworks for distribution networks 
remain under evolution, with utilities 
expected to follow established 
internal protocols until national 
standards are formalised.
Outlook
India’s power distribution sector is 
witnessing rapid and transformative 
growth, driven by the twin goals of 
meeting rising electricity demand 
and enhancing supply reliability. 
Ongoing reforms emphasise reducing 
technical and commercial losses, 
strengthening the financial health of 
DISCOMs, and modernising networks 
through smart grid technologies. The 
government’s Revamped Distribution 
Sector Scheme (RDSS) is accelerating 
this transition by promoting smart 
metering, loss reduction, and 
improved service quality. Meanwhile, 
proposed legislative changes aim to 
liberalise the market, encouraging 
private sector participation and 
fostering competition and innovation. 
With digitalisation and grid 
modernisation at its core, the sector 
is pivotal to integrating renewable 
energy and advancing India’s clean 
energy transition towards a more 
resilient and sustainable power 
system by 2030 and beyond.

Policies and Government Initiatives
India’s Energy Transition 
India’s energy transition is underpinned by a comprehensive and evolving policy framework that aims to simultaneously 
address energy access, affordability, security, and sustainability. Through a series of well-orchestrated central schemes, 
fiscal incentives, regulatory reforms, and market mechanisms, the government has laid a robust foundation to accelerate 
investments across the power value chain.
Clean Energy Expansion and 
Renewable Integration
India has set an ambitious target of 
achieving 500 GW of non-fossil fuel 
generated power capacity by 2030. 
This goal is aligned with the nation’s 
pledge to cut the emission intensity of 
its GDP by 45% from 2005 levels and 
attain Net Zero targets by 2070. To 
support this goal, the government has 
institutionalised multiple programmes: 
 Green Energy Corridor (GEC): 
Facilitates evacuation of renewable 
power from generation zones to 
demand centres. In 2024-25 alone, 
INR 6 Billion was allocated to expand 
transmission lines and substations 
under GEC-II and GEC-III 
 Production-Linked Incentive (PLI) 
Scheme: Originally targeted 50 
GWh of advanced-chemistry-
cell (ACC) manufacturing with 
an outlay of INR 18,100 Crore. 
By mid-2025, the scheme was 
under reassessment as several 
beneficiaries—including Ola 
Electric, Reliance New Energy, 
and Rajesh Exports—missed 
commissioning milestones and 
sought deadline extensions
 Renewable Energy Zones (REZs): 
Created in high-potential regions 
like Rajasthan, Gujarat, and Tamil 
Nadu, with expedited clearances 
and viability gap funding (VGF) to 
ensure timely infrastructure rollouts  
 VGF: Approved for offshore wind 
projects totalling 1,000 MW, further 
diversifying the renewable mix
Energy Storage and Grid 
Modernisation 
Recognising energy storage as 
a critical enabler of firm and 
dispatchable renewable power, the 
government introduced multiple 
mandates and incentives:
 Energy Storage Obligation (ESO): 
Requires discoms and load serving 
entities to procure a minimum 
share of stored energy, scaling 
from 1% in FY 2023-24 to 4% by FY 
2029-30, with 85% to be derived 
from renewables 
 BESS Mandate: MoP guidelines 
issued in February 2025 require 
a minimum of 2-hour storage to 
be co-located with 10% of solar 
capacity in all new bids 
 Financial Support: SECI’s SIGHT-II 
programme awarded INR 22.39 
Billion in incentives to 3 GW of green 
hydrogen and electrolyser capacity 
Distribution Sector Reforms 
and Subsidy Rationalisation
 Revamped Distribution Sector 
Scheme (RDSS): With a total outlay 
of INR 3.04 Trillion, the scheme 
targets AT&C loss reduction to  
12-15% and aims to close the ACS-
ARR gap
 Electricity Rules (Rights of 
Consumers): Enhances service 
accountability with compensation 
frameworks, minimum supply hours, 
and billing transparency norms 
 ISTS Charge Waiver Extension 
(June 2025): The Ministry of Power 
extended the 100% waiver of 
inter-state-transmission-system 
(ISTS) charges to include co-
located battery energy storage 
systems (BESS) and pumped-
storage hydropower projects 
commissioned by June 30, 2028, 
broadening the earlier exemption 
for solar/wind projects 
 VGF for BESS Capacity: The 
government announced INR 9,100 
Crore of VGF support for 43.2 GWh 
of battery-storage projects, further 
reinforcing policy focus on grid 
flexibility. 
 Grid Intelligence: Investments 
through RDSS and IPDS support 
SCADA, AMI, WAMS, and DMS 
technologies to enhance grid 
responsiveness
 Electricity Distribution (Accounts 
and Additional Disclosure) Rules, 
2024: Mandates provisioning for 
receivables, quarterly disclosures, 
and improved subsidy accounting 
 Late Payment Surcharge (LPSC) 
Mechanism: Provides structured 
EMI-based frameworks to clear 
legacy dues of discoms, lowering 
payment risks for generators and 
transmission licensees
82 Semi Annual Report 2025-26
Outlook
India’s power sector policy 
architecture is gradually shifting 
from asset creation to system 
integration. With robust push 
towards clean technology 
manufacturing, grid digitisation, 
financial reform, and regional 
cooperation, India is laying the 
groundwork for an efficient, resilient, 
and green energy ecosystem. The 
alignment of sectoral policies with 
broader macro goals like energy 
security, employment generation, 
and climate leadership will 
continue to attract domestic and 
global capital, while ensuring long-
term sectoral viability.
Hydrogen, Decarbonisation, 
and Critical Minerals 
Strategy
 National Green Hydrogen Mission: 
Aims to achieve 5 Million metric 
tonnes of annual green hydrogen 
production by 2030. As of FY 
2024–25, India has sanctioned 
over 862,000 tonnes per annum 
of production capacity and 3 GW 
of electrolyser manufacturing 
projects under the mission
 Fiscal Incentives: The Union 
Budget 2025–26 has earmarked 
INR 600 Crore to support pilot 
projects and decentralised green 
hydrogen applications, fostering 
early adoption and innovation
 Critical Minerals Mission: With an 
approved outlay of INR 163 Billion, 
the mission promotes exploration, 
processing, and recycling of 
essential minerals such as lithium 
and cobalt, complemented by 
duty exemptions on cobalt powder 
and lithium-ion battery scrap to 
strengthen India’s clean energy 
supply chain
Private Sector Enablement 
and Market Reforms
 Tariff-Based Competitive Bidding 
(TBCB): Continues to be the 
dominant route for awarding ISTS 
projects, fostering transparency 
and efficiency 
 Real-Time Market (RTM) and 
Green Day-Ahead Market 
(GDAM): Operationalised to allow 
renewable generators greater 
scheduling flexibility and access to 
markets
 Regulatory Simplification: 
Streamlined processes for 
open access, net metering, and 
captive generation are helping 
debottleneck private participation
 Complementary Storage Policies: 
Recent ISTS charge waivers and 
ESS asset recognition collectively 
strengthen the market framework 
for storage-linked renewable 
participation

Cross-Border and Regional 
Energy Trade
The Central Electricity Authority (CEA) 
and Ministry of Power are actively 
promoting regional cooperation with 
neighbouring countries. Cross-border 
trade guidelines have been updated 
to support seasonal balancing, surplus 
renewable export, and harmonised 
grid planning with Nepal, Bhutan, 
Bangladesh, and Myanmar. India’s 
cross-border transmission capacity 
stood at ~13,998 MW in early 2025.

Infrastructure Investment Trusts (InvITs): 
Catalysing Capital for India’s  
Infrastructure Needs
InvITs have firmly established 
themselves as a key enabler of 
infrastructure financing in India. As 
of September 30, 2025, there were 26 
InvITs registered with SEBI, spanning 
sectors such as roads, power 
transmission, renewable energy, 
telecom towers, and logistics. Among 
these, 5 are publicly listed and rest 
are privately placed. 
Collectively, InvITs manage assets 
worth approximately INR 6 Lakh 
Crore and have raised INR 1.2 Lakh 
Crore in equity since 2019. The five 
publicly listed InvITs now command 
a combined market capitalisation of 
approximately INR 30,500 Crore and 
serve over 2.4 Lakh unitholders. This 
reflects growing interest from both 
institutional and retail investors.
Regulatory support has been 
instrumental in nurturing this 
asset class. SEBI introduced key 
amendments to improve liquidity 
and flexibility in FY 2024-25, easing 
lock-in requirements for preferential 
allotments and permitting inter se 
transfer of locked-in units among 
sponsors and their group entities. In 
addition, new guidelines for follow-
on public offers were issued to 
streamline fundraising and enable 
fast-track issuance. Complementary 
policy reforms such as the inclusion 
of InvITs in the investment mandates 
of insurance companies, pension 
funds, and foreign portfolio investors 
(FPIs), along with the reduction of the 
minimum trading lot size to one unit, 
have enhanced market accessibility 
and deepened participation.
From an operational perspective, 
InvITs like IndiGrid exemplify how 
the model enables scalable asset 
ownership and efficient capital 
recycling. IndiGrid, India’s largest  
listed power sector InvIT, has 
expanded its Assets Under 
Management (AUM) to around INR 
296 Billion through a combination 
of acquisitions and greenfield 
investments spanning transmission, 
solar, and battery energy storage. 
This performance underscores the 
increasing investor appetite for long-
duration, annuity-like cash flows 
supported by critical infrastructure 
assets. With a regulatory requirement 
to distribute at least 90% of Net 
Distributable Cash Flows (NDCF) to 
unitholders, InvITs continue to offer 
attractive, stable yields.
Looking ahead, InvITs are maturing 
into mainstream financing platforms 
for infrastructure, anchored by clear 
regulations, improving operational 
performance, and increasing 
institutional interest. Their role is 
expected to expand further with the 
rising private sector participation, 
particularly in the context of the 
National Monetisation Pipeline and 
India’s accelerating energy transition.
84 Semi Annual Report 2025-26
Key Functions of InvITs
Equity Raise
InvITs raise capital 
through primary 
equity issuances 
from institutional 
and retail investors 
to fund asset 
acquisitions and 
expansion.
Debt Raise
They secure 
borrowings from 
banks, NBFCs, and 
capital markets, 
while maintaining 
leverage within the 
70% Net Debt to 
AUM ceiling.
Acquire
InvITs acquire 
commercially 
operational 
infrastructure 
assets, which must 
comprise at least 
80% of their AUM, 
using a mix of 
equity and debt.
Revenue 
Generation
Revenues are 
generated through 
availability-
based or user-
based charges 
from operating 
assets, which are 
actively managed 
for optimal 
performance.
Distribution
InvITs are 
mandated to 
distribute at least 
90% of their NDCF 
to unitholders as 
Distribution Per 
Unit (DPU), which 
may include 
dividends, interest, 
capital repayment, 
and other income.

Focus on Maximising ‘Reliability’
In accordance with the Assured 
Performance pillar of the Asset 
Management Framework, 
predictable reliability is of paramount 
importance to achieve committed 
performance for our stakeholders. 
IndiGrid has adopted the Reliability-
Reliability depends upon predictability, 
and predictability is achieved through 
the right methods and tools.
The traditional approach to routine 
maintenance works for easily 
detectable, low-risk issues that 
are addressed on a periodic basis. 
While this largely fulfils the statutory 
requirements, this approach is less 
effective for an efficient and reliable 
asset performance.
IndiGrid has augmented traditional 
routine maintenance, with various 
predictive methodologies. This way 
it has moved from conventional 
corrective (or reactive or run to failure 
approach) to more effective predictive, 
preventive and reliability centred 
maintenance. 
Centered (RC) approach to achieve 
the objective of safe and reliable 
operations of assets. 
The RC approach is the process 
of determining the most effective 
maintenance strategies based 
on the local and global leading 
Implementation of technologies 
like drone-based inspection, use 
of AI-based image analytics, and 
investigative technologies such as TFR, 
electric field modelling, corona imaging, 
EFD/IR have helped significantly 
in taking timely interventions on 
transmission lines. Rigorous testing of 
our substation equipment involving 
regular DGA on oil-filled equipment, Tan 
Delta tests on bushings, windings, and 
CTs, regular CRM and DCRM tests on 
circuit breakers, and regular protection 
audits, among others, have yielded 
better reliability across our transmission 
portfolio. 
Further digitisation of asset 
management processes and 
implementation of tools like Maximo, 
Asset Health Index, and RAS have 
enhanced data integrity, response time 
practices across sectors, particularly 
in power transmission. The success 
of approach is well demonstrated by 
the consistent drop in the Trips/ Un-
scheduled outages and an increase 
in reliability over the past five years.
and monitoring of vital performance 
parameters with respect to the baseline, 
helping timely interventions.
Going forward, online technologies 
such as DGA instruments, SF6 leakage 
detection cameras, and a digital 
asset lifecycle management platform 
with artificial intelligence-based 
transformative technologies, along 
with robust emergency management 
programmes featuring an inbuilt state-
of-the-art SCADA system, will further 
strengthen IndiGrid’s RC approach to 
enable the Company to deliver its vision 
and objectives.
IndiGrid is accredited with IMS 
certification for ISO 9001, ISO 14000, ISO 
45000 quality and safety management 
systems, and ISO 27001 for the 
cybersecurity management system.
The IndiGrid Reliability-Centered (RC) approach is illustrated as:
